description.narrative: The project supports removal of barriers to the adoption of wind energy in Belarus pragmatically.

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

description.narrative:
Installation of at least 25 MW of wind power utilizing market based investments with average net capacity factors over 30% which will produce the objective of generating >1 million MWh of renewable energy and reducing greenhouse gas emissions by > 500,000 tonnes of CO2 equivalent
Outcome 1: 1.1. A financeable feed-in-tariff including transmission charges 1.2. Rules and procedures for grid connection
Outcome 2: 2.1.Clear guidelines and viable examples of Wind Farm investments in place 2.2. Developed and published manuals
Outcome 3: 3.1. Availability of adequate funding for the WPFI and the PMU 3.2. Selection of an outside consultant capable of performing the development work 3.3. Installation of at least five meteorological towers are installed and data is collected for at least one year. 3.4. The WPFI, a private entity, obtains permits and Investment Agreements for at least 5 projects 3.5. The WPFI, a private entity, successfully tenders at least 5 projects and finds acceptable level of investor interest
Outcome 4: 4.1. WPFI, a private entity, develops 5 wind farms which developers purchase and proceed to construction.

comment.narrative:
Zero; <5 MW
Outcome 1: 1.1. RE Law 1.2. RE Law
Outcome 2: 2.1. 0 2.2. 0
Outcome 3: 3.1. Zero 3.2. Zero 3.3. 1 3.4. 0 3.5. 0
Outcome 4: 4.1. <5 MW

1. Secondary Legislation is in place to support wind energy with the support of the project 2. Reduce regulatory risks for investments in wind power in Belarus to the point that at least 5 wind farms are developed, financed, and eventually constructed 3. Wind Energy Project Technical Assistance Facility is established to support the WPFI investment in and the development of documentation for at least 25 MW of wind power. 4. At least 5 wind farm projects are successfully developed and the Wind Energy Support Unit continues to operate past the lifetime of the project.

1. Best European practice and policies, in particular for the State RES Cadastre, RES Inventory as well as secondary legislation, which was developed in previous years, were introduced to general public, including youth, at a workshop in the village of Obidemlya. Due to enforcement of the developed secondary legislation, the investor for the site in Veleshkovichi, for which the pre-development stage was complete in the framework of the project, was successfully selected and the purchase contract was signed. The strategy of the development of Renewable energy in Belarus was finalized.
2. Decision makers, mainly the authorities of MNREP, Ministry of Energy, Department of Energy Efficiency took part in the project Steering Committee meetings. RE related curricula were additionally introduced in specialized secondary training – colleges. For the first time in Belarus a group of technicians, half of them women, doing maintenance of wind turbines were trained in Global Wind Organization safety procedures and received certificates. Several new manuals on wind energy development were finalized and the guidelines for investors were reviewed and updated. Some of the manuals and briefs were published and disseminated.
3. The sites where the construction of the wind farms is planned (Veleshkovichi (Liozno district, Vitebsk region)and Yanovichi (Novogrudok, Grodno region) sites in particular) were attended by the PMU to verify the preliminary conditions for the connection to the grid. As a result of the study tour to Sweden the proposals for the development of wind power and RES in general were submitted to the Council of Ministers of the Republic of Belarus. Modeling of the energy balance of Belarus taking into account the commissioning of nuclear power station and the development of RES was performed. The wind measurement equipment calibration finalized a one-year wind measurement campaign for the four out of five project wind power development sites. Thus, the project prepared five wind measurement reports prepared and verified in accordance with MEASNET requirements. The WPFI operated in accordance with the Terms of Reference and the Charter, monthly reports on the activities of the WPFI were provided to the Ministry of Environment and approved by the Ministry of Environment. During the reporting period WPFI organized the investor contest and auction for the competitive sale of the first pre-investment asset – VES “Veleshkovichi”, Ltd. with the right to develop 25 MW wind farm in Veleshkovichi, Liozno district, Vitebsk region. The pre-investment asset for the construction of a wind farm near the village of Veleshkovichi, Liozno district of the Vitebsk region was sold and transferred to the investor (Turkish company Guris) after clearance of the purchase contract by the Ministry of Antimonopoly Regulation and Trade. To boost the interest of the potential investors at the contest the Information (investment) memorandum on Veleshkovichi site was prepared. It was presented in two languages in the form of a Power point presentation as well as in printed brochures at the First Impact Investment Forum in Minsk on March 28, 2019 as well as it was sent out to the potential investors at the time of the investment tender. The data necessary for the Power Purchase Agreement for the project in Veleshkovichi were prepared. Monitoring of the activity of the implementation of the project for the construction of a 25 MW wind farm in the village of Veleshkovichi started, the project is kept updated by the investor on the progress with the project. An independent assessment of the value of the pre-investment asset for the construction of a wind farm near the village of Veleshkovichi was carried out. The assessed value was treated as the initial price of the pre-investment asset Veleshkovichi at the auction. An independent assessment of the process of pre-qualification of investors was undertaken by the international consultant hired by UNDP. The 50th session of the Subsidiary Body for Implementation (SBI50) and the 50th session of the Subsidiary Body for Scientific and Technological Advice (SBSTA50) in Bonn was attended by the two representatives of MNREP from 17 to 27 June 2019 to ensure that the climate issues positively impact the further development of wind power in Belarus – the relevant suggestions were presented in their mission reports. The workshop attended by 50 representatives of state bodies, experts, representatives of public organizations was held on June 7-8 as part of the 15th Republican Environmental Forum. The project also presented its exposition on wind energy at a general exhibition organized as part of the Forum. The annual seminar on the future prospects of wind energy development in Belarus attended by 40 participants was held on December 26, 2019
4. The contract for the services on Validation of data of Wind Atlas of Belarus, upgrade of the Wind Atlas as an important informational resource for wind energy developers and investors was concluded, the results will be obtained in 2020. The contract for Conducting an analysis of the reliability of daily prediction of the generation of electricity from wind based on the weather forecasts during at least 12 calendar months using modern numerical models and forecasting methods for meteorological phenomena was concluded, the results will be obtained in 2020. The project’s website was kept up to date in Russian and English, the number of users was increasing monthly. For the duration of the project, all relevant documents were posted on the projects website - www.windpower.by., Including 83 articles, reviews, press releases. 6 public relations events were held during the year on the theme of the project.

1. Secondary Legislation is in place to support wind energy with the support of the project. 2. Reduce regulatory risks for investments in wind power in Belarus to the point that at least 5 wind farms are developed, financed, and eventually constructed. 3. Wind Energy Project Technical Assistance Facility is established to support the WPFI investment in and the development of documentation for at least 25 MW of wind power 4. At least 5 wind farm projects are successfully developed and the Wind Energy Support Unit continues to operate past the lifetime of the project

1. The fully updated State Cadaster of renewable energy sources became an important information sources and a tool for the wind energy developers and investors, regulatory bodies and wind public. The online Internet source provides up-to-date information on the existing installations as well as on the potential sites for wind power development. The Wind Energy Support Unit (WESU) oversees its regular update and functioning. This resources is well coordinated with the other informational source developed under the project – Wind Atlas of Belarus. The project prepared a comprehensive background for the introduction of “green” energy certification in Belarus. Including carbon market aspects that touch upon wind energy. The materials include not only international and national analytical reports but also draft legal acts and an implementation scheme. The importance of the certification system was also explained at project workshops and study tours. Due to the Project some amendments to the secondary legislation on renewable energy sources relating to the implementation of the RES project by the investors attracted as a result of the international technical assistance projects implementation were successfully introduced. 2. Reduction of regulatory and other investment risks for wind energy in Belarus started with a de-risking study, the outcomes of which were based not only on economic analysis but also on practical evaluation of the investment situation in Belarus. As a result, a number of rated risks were identified and the measures to reduce or eliminate them were proposed. 3. Wind Private Finance Initiative (WPFI) was legally formed as LLC Wind Private Finance Initiative and played a key role in pre-investment development of five wind farms of 60.7 MW installed capacity. WPFI established five legal entities dedicated for five selected sites for the future wind energy development; coordinated wind measurement work and preparation of bankable reports; consolidated developed documentation for the investment tender. WPFI organized the first investment open auction with the support of the Belarusian Universal Commodities Exchange and continues similar activity with the remaining four sites (which, unfortunately, had not been granted quotas for wind energy installations construction during the time of the project implementation). WPFI also continues work on the selection of the sites and wind measurements taking (using the wind measurement equipment procured under the project). The success and efficiency of WPFI work depends a lot on the overall situation with renewable energy development in the country. The project made the maximum use of its capacity to improve the perception of wind energy in different target groups (the energy balance of the country presupposing enhancement of wind power installed capacity was developed; practical assessment of wind energy impact on fauna was undertaken, the possibilities of use of “smart” grids to enhance wind energy installed capacity were considered). The first pre-investment asset – LLC VES Veleskhovichi was sold to the Turkish company Guris, which is continuing development now and plan to complete the wind farm by December 2022. 4. The work on modernization of Wind Atlas of Belarus was completed. As a result, the Atlas was registered as an informational resource and now is available for the public at https://atlas.pogoda.by/#//. WESU uses Atlas and State Cadaster of RES to identify the most promising areas for future wind energy developments, prepare informational materials for the potential investors and local authorities to facilitate wind energy construction. WESU also takes an active part in the formation of secondary legislation on renewables using analytical reports prepared under the project. Analysis of the reliability of daily prediction of the generation of electricity from wind based on the weather forecasts using modern numerical models and forecasting methods for meteorological phenomena was completed, a methodology for energy production forecast based on weather forecast was prepared. This work will be continued as the proper energy output forecast depends on accuracy and frequency of the weather forecast. The project’s website was kept up to date in Russian and English and became a major source of information about the project and wind energy investment in Belarus. The development of five pre-investment assets for the construction of 5 wind farms of the installed capacity of 60.7 MW was supported by a number of PR events – at least 5 such events per year had been held.

1. Secondary Legislation is in place to support wind energy with the support of the project. 2. Reduce regulatory risks for investments in wind power in Belarus to the point that at least 5 wind farms are developed, financed, and eventually constructed. 3. Wind Energy Project Technical Assistance Facility is established to support the WPFI investment in and the development of documentation for at least 25 MW of wind power. 4. At least 5 wind farm projects are successfully developed and the Wind Energy Support Unit continues to operate past the lifetime of the project

1.The fully updated State Cadaster of renewable energy sources became an important information sources and a tool for the wind energy developers and investors, regulatory bodies and wind public. The online Internet source provides up-to-date information on the existing installations as well as on the potential sites for wind power development. The Wind Energy Support Unit (WESU) oversees its regular update and functioning. This resources is well coordinated with the other informational source developed under the project – Wind Atlas of Belarus. The project prepared a comprehensive background for the introduction of “green” energy certification in Belarus. Including carbon market aspects that touch upon wind energy. The materials include not only international and national analytical reports but also draft legal acts and an implementation scheme. The importance of the certification system was also explained at project workshops and study tours. Due to the Project some amendments to the secondary legislation on renewable energy sources relating to the implementation of the RES project by the investors attracted as a result of the international technical assistance projects implementation were successfully introduced. 2. Reduction of regulatory and other investment risks for wind energy in Belarus started with a de-risking study, the outcomes of which were based not only on economic analysis but also on practical evaluation of the investment situation in Belarus. As a result, a number of rated risks were identified and the measures to reduce or eliminate them were proposed. 3. Wind Private Finance Initiative (WPFI) was legally formed as LLC Wind Private Finance Initiative and played a key role in pre-investment development of five wind farms of 60.7 MW installed capacity. WPFI established five legal entities dedicated for five selected sites for the future wind energy development; coordinated wind measurement work and preparation of bankable reports; consolidated developed documentation for the investment tender. WPFI organized the first investment open auction with the support of the Belarusian Universal Commodities Exchange and continues similar activity with the remaining four sites (which, unfortunately, had not been granted quotas for wind energy installations construction during the time of the project implementation). WPFI also continues work on the selection of the sites and wind measurements taking (using the wind measurement equipment procured under the project). The success and efficiency of WPFI work depends a lot on the overall situation with renewable energy development in the country. The project made the maximum use of its capacity to improve the perception of wind energy in different target groups (the energy balance of the country presupposing enhancement of wind power installed capacity was developed; practical assessment of wind energy impact on fauna was undertaken, the possibilities of use of “smart” grids to enhance wind energy installed capacity were considered). The first pre-investment asset – LLC VES Veleskhovichi was sold to the Turkish company Guris, which is continuing development now and plan to complete the wind farm by December 2022. 4. The work on modernization of Wind Atlas of Belarus was completed. As a result, the Atlas was registered as an informational resource and now is available for the public at https://atlas.pogoda.by/#//. WESU uses Atlas and State Cadaster of RES to identify the most promising areas for future wind energy developments, prepare informational materials for the potential investors and local authorities to facilitate wind energy construction. WESU also takes an active part in the formation of secondary legislation on renewables using analytical reports prepared under the project. Analysis of the reliability of daily prediction of the generation of electricity from wind based on the weather forecasts using modern numerical models and forecasting methods for meteorological phenomena was completed, a methodology for energy production forecast based on weather forecast was prepared. This work will be continued as the proper energy output forecast depends on accuracy and frequency of the weather forecast. The project’s website was kept up to date in Russian and English and became a major source of information about the project and wind energy investment in Belarus. The development of five pre-investment assets for the construction of 5 wind farms of the installed capacity of 60.7 MW was supported by a number of PR events – at least 5 such events per year had been held.

Outcome 1: 1.1 Develop and agree provisions for institutional infrastructure based on the best European practice and policies, in particular for the State RES Cadastre, RES Inventory, and validation systems. 1.2 Formulated and enforced Secondary Legislation. 1.3 New/Improved Technical Norms and Standards. Outcome 2: 2.1 Awareness-raising program for decision makers. 2.4 Completed support for ancillary services. Outcome 3: 3.1 Completed support provided for potential site developments. 3.2 Identify and evaluate available public and private debt and equity financing for above site developments. 3.3 Completed support for the preparation of development work on the targeted sites. Outcome 4: 4.2 Completed Web portal for the project 4.4 Developed, reviewed, revised, finalized and published Lessons Learned study

Outcome 1: 1.1 The RES Cadaster is published in an updated form on the Internet. Based on the analytical work carried out in 2017, draft legal acts are prepared that ensure the functioning of the energy certification system produced by RES and the carbon market, which have been agreed with the stakeholders and submitted to the lawmaking body. At least 20 participants of the event - representatives of local executive and administrative bodies of the Grodno region, MNREP, RUE BelRC Ecology, Belenergo, the Department for Energy Efficiency, public organizations, the project - expanded their knowledge on the current issues of forming the normative base for wind energy, raised their professional level, receiving current information on the formation of tariffs for RES, the impact of wind power on the environment, the impact of RES facilities on the network, the State Cadastre of RES. 1.2 The number of attracted qualified investors to participate in the first auction for the sale of a pre-investment asset is at least. The minutes of the relevant meetings and negotiations, approved by MNREP, are prepared. The developed draft of the legal act on the approval of the Strategy is approved by MNREP and the main stakeholders and submitted to the law-making body. The draft resolution of the Council of Ministers of the Republic of Belarus On the Approval of the Regulation on the Procedure for the Formation of Prices for Electric Energy Produced Using Renewable Energy Sources and the justification for its adoption are approved by the main government bodies concerned and submitted to the law-making body. 1.3 The Scientific and Production Republican Unitary Enterprise Belarusian State Institute for Standardization and Certification (BelGiss) together with the individual consultant, developed tseveral technical legal acts. At least 50 participants representing the Parliament of the Republic of Belarus, MNREP, the Ministry of Energy, the Department for Energy Efficiency, the MART, the Ministry of Taxes and Tax Collection, the Ministry of Economy, the Ministry of Finance, public organizations, the project have increased their level of knowledge on the development of the legislative framework (including the contribution of RES to the fight against change climate), got acquainted with the draft documents developed within the framework of the project in the current year. Outcome 2: 2.1 2 sessions of the Project Steering Committee are held per year. 10 articles, 5 reviews, 4 information sheets prepared and posted on the project website. 2.4 30 people - representatives of the Parliament of the Republic of Belarus, MNREP, the Ministry of Energy, the Department for Energy Efficiency, the MART, the Ministry of Taxes and Tax Collection, the Ministry of Economy, the Ministry of Finance, public organizations, the project - took part in the discussion of topical issues of the power system balance development in Belarus; got familiar with at least three models of the development of the balance of the energy system of Belarus. As a result, a protocol is prepared with the comments and wishes of the participants, the protocol is sent to MNREP, the Ministry of Energy, the Department of Energy Efficiency. The created video is posted on the Internet. Outcome 3: 3.1 The cooperation agreement between MNREP (which includes WESU) and LLC Wind Private Finance Initiative is prepared and signed in accordance with the established procedure. A report on potential investors and financial organizations interested in cooperation with the Project is prepared and approved by MNREP. 8 experts - representatives of MNREP, Ministry of Energy, Belenergo, the Department for Energy Efficiency studied the international experience in transferring energy produced by RES to the grid, as well as experience in other aspects of wind energy development, prepared proposals for optimizing the process of transfer of energy produced by RES, as well as on the development of wind power in Belarus in general. Several models of the balance of the energy system of Belarus are developed in accordance with the planned strategic vision for the development of renewable energy sources and wind power in particular.Based on the developed models, recommendations are prepared for stakeholders on the development of relevant normative legal acts. The semi-annual phase of the wind measurement campaign is finalized, a corresponding report is prepared and adopted by MNREP. Dismantling equipment owned by Belhydromet is dismantled at 2 sites for further use in wind-measuring campaigns for updating the Atlas of wind potential. he WPFI carries out its activities in accordance with the Terms of Reference and the Charter, monthly reports on the activities of the WPFI are provided in MNREP and approved by MNREP. A methodology for monitoring research in Belarus is developed. The project design documentation for the Veleskovichi site is developed and approved. 3.2 The most likely partners of the WPFI are identified; a corresponding report is prepared and approved by MNREP. 3.3 At least 12 specialists from MNREP, the Ministry of Energy, the Department for Energy Efficiency, the MART, the Ministry of Finance raised their level of knowledge about the planning, financing and implementation of the project for the construction of a wind farm, and also increased their professional potential to attract partners and investors to implement renewable energy projects in Belarus . Outcome 4: 4.2 The website of the project is maintained in an up-to-date state, the number of users increases monthly. 80 articles, reviews, press releases are prepared and posted on the site. 5 PR events are held. Preparation and printing of brochures on 1) EIA - of circulation 200 copies; and 2) De-risking study – 100 copies. 4.4 Mid-term review of the project implementation is undertaken, a relevant report is prepared and approved by UNDP and MNREP.
